text: Nuclear factor-kappaB induction in <extra_id_0> CD45RO <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> + and <extra_id_0> CD45RA <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> + T cell subsets during aging .
An increase in the ratio of memory to naive T cells has been postulated to underlie immune hyporesponsiveness accompanying aging .

Our analyses of the induction of nuclear factor-kappaB ( NFkappaB ) in activated memory ( <extra_id_0> CD45RO <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> + ) and naive ( <extra_id_0> CD45RA <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> + ) T cell subsets from young and elderly donors has demonstrated that , regardless of donor age , memory T cells are not significantly altered in their responsiveness to <extra_id_0> TNF-alpha <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - mediated induction of NFkappaB .

Although treatment with <extra_id_0> TNF-alpha <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> induced nuclear localization of NFkappaB in both memory and naive T cell subsets , irrespective of the age of the donor , the levels of induced NFkappaB were significantly lower in both subsets of T cells obtained from the elderly , when compared to those in young .

Examination of <extra_id_0> IkappaB alpha <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> regulation revealed that <extra_id_0> TNF-alpha <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - mediated degradation of <extra_id_0> IkappaB alpha <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> in both memory and naive T cells from the elderly was severely impaired , thus contributing to the lowered induction of the observed NFkappaB .

text: In addition , this age-related decrease in induction of nuclear NFkappaB correlated with decrease in intracellular IL-2 receptor expression and anti-CD3 - induced proliferation of both memory and naive T cells subsets .
Taken together , our results suggest that the age-related hyporesponsiveness can not be attributed to a skewing of the T cell population towards a memory phenotype in the elderly .
